wikipedia_page.main: Richard Cornthwaite Lambert (5 May 1868 – 5 November 1939) was a British barrister and Liberal Party politician

response: * Richard Cornthwaite Lambert (1868–1939), barrister and politician

link_mentions.page: List of members of London County Council 1889–1919

response: Lambert was born in Kingston upon Thames, England, and was the son of Richard Cornthwaite Lambert a barrister and Liberal Party politician. He was educated at Repton School and Wadham College, Oxford, where he studied Classics. Some of his poems were published in the Oxford University literary magazine Oxford Poetry, then in its formative years. After leaving Oxford, he worked as a sub-editor with The Economist from 1914–1915, joining the staff in 1916.

The Liberal Party approached Arthur Neal, then a local councillor, but he declined nomination.  Only one candidate then put themselves forward for nomination: Richard Cornthwaite Lambert, a London-based barrister who had narrowly failed to win Sheffield Ecclesall at the 1906 election."Sheffield Election: the Liberal Candidate", Manchester Guardian, 19 April 1909
